Bump jquery from 3.4.1 to 3.5.0 (#731) Summary: Bumps [jquery](https://github.com/jquery/jquery) from 3.4.1 to 3.5.0.
Commits
  • 7a0a850 3.5.0
  • 8570a08 Release: Update AUTHORS.txt
  • da3dd85 Ajax: Do not execute scripts for unsuccessful HTTP responses
  • 065143c Ajax: Overwrite s.contentType with content-type header value, if any
  • 1a4f10d Tests: Blacklist one focusin test in IE
  • 9e15d6b Event: Use only one focusin/out handler per matching window & document
  • 966a709 Manipulation: Skip the select wrapper for <option> outside of IE 9
  • 1d61fd9 Manipulation: Make jQuery.htmlPrefilter an identity function
  • 04bf577 Selector: Update Sizzle from 2.3.4 to 2.3.5
  • 7506c9c Build: Resolve Travis config warnings
  • Additional commits viewable in compare view
Maintainer changes

This version was pushed to npm by mgol, a new releaser for jquery since your current version.

You can achieve the same result by closing it manually - `dependabot ignore this major version` will close this PR and stop Dependabot creating any more for this major version (unless you reopen the PR or upgrade to it yourself) - `dependabot ignore this minor version` will close this PR and stop Dependabot creating any more for this minor version (unless you reopen the PR or upgrade to it yourself) - `dependabot ignore this dependency` will close this PR and stop Dependabot creating any more for this dependency (unless you reopen the PR or upgrade to it yourself) - `dependabot use these labels` will set the current labels as the default for future PRs for this repo and language - `dependabot use these reviewers` will set the current reviewers as the default for future PRs for this repo and language - `dependabot use these assignees` will set the current assignees as the default for future PRs for this repo and language - `dependabot use this milestone` will set the current milestone as the default for future PRs for this repo and language You can disable automated security fix PRs for this repo from the [Security Alerts page](https://github.com/facebookresearch/visdom/network/alerts).
Pull Request resolved: https://github.com/facebookresearch/visdom/pull/731 Reviewed By: lvdmaaten Differential Revision: D21478858 Pulled By: JackUrb fbshipit-source-id: 84f4b4d2dd68281e236a397076ccce983240a41e

Support Latex in Visdom (#728)

Summary:
Visdom will support the latex.
## Description

The MathJax Library has some issues while working locally. Whereas using the cdnjs cloud, it was working well.
Hence, introduced the MathJax in the static js folder which will directly get installed while installing Visdom.
## Motivation and Context

Had seen many queries and found how much it a need for the people using Visdom for their project.
Hence, thought of helping everyone in need of this feature.
The following issues will get resolved:
https://github.com/facebookresearch/visdom/issues/723

## How Has This Been Tested?

Yes, I have tested it and have updated the demo.py.
Here is an example and the screenshot of the output is added accordingly.
```
import visdom
import numpy as np
viz = visdom.Visdom()

viz.line(
	X=[1, 2, 3, 4],
	Y=[1, 4, 9, 16],
	win="latex_support",
	name=r'$\alpha_{1c} = 352 \pm 11 \text{ km s}^{-1}$',
	update='append',
	opts=dict(
	showlegend=True,
	title="Demo Latex in Visdom",
	xlabel=r'$\sqrt{(n_\text{c}(t|{T_\text{early}}))}$',
	ylabel=r'$d, r \text{ (solar radius)}$',
	)
)
viz.line(
	X=[1, 2, 3, 4],
	Y=[0.5, 2, 4.5, 8],
	win="latex_support",
	name=r'$\beta_{1c} = 25 \pm 11 \text{ km s}^{-1}$',
	update='append',
)
```
## Screenshots (if appropriate):
![Latex Support](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/33365560/78450029-47820a80-7699-11ea-8ba4-9f396cc3a887.gif)

## Types of changes

- [x] Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)
- [x] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality)
- [ ] Breaking change (fix or feature that would cause existing functionality to not work as expected)

- [x] My change requires a change to the documentation.
- [x] I have updated the documentation accordingly.
- [x] For JavaScript changes, I have re-generated the minified JavaScript code.

Add new feature Double Y Axis Lines (#719)

Summary:
One can apply two different scales of data on the same linear plot.

## Description
This plot will display two lines with different y axis. Hence, it will help in plot two different arrays with different values together on the same plot.

## Motivation and Context

I want to compare my training and testing data. But that was not feasible using the single line plot. Hence, introduced a new feature.
## How Has This Been Tested?

Here is the code, that I have used for testing it:
```
import visdom
import numpy as np
import time
viz = visdom.Visdom()
viz.delete_env("testing")
viz.env = "testing"
opts=dict(
    side='right',
    nameY1='Training',
    nameY2='Testing',
)
while True:
    X=np.arange(20)
    Y1=np.random.randint(0,20,20)
    Y2=np.random.randint(100,200,20)
    viz.double_yaxis_lines(X,Y1,Y2,win="test",opts=opts)
    time.sleep(2)
```
## Screenshots (if appropriate):
![double_y_axis](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/33365560/77659609-4c123900-6f9e-11ea-9954-b73fbda24a29.gif)

fbshipit-source-id: d1597e045b654d8bbfe1600acdafbe44f0996f73

Marker border line width override (#623) (#696)

Summary:
## Description
Provide a way to change the width of the black border around every point in a
scatter plot from 0.5. A new opt `opts.markerborderwidth` provides the new value.

## Motivation and Context
If you want to use color in a meaningful way in a scatter plot, the
hardcoded black border gets in the way. This is worse when you have
a lot of points in a scatter plot. One use case is plotting an RGB
pointcloud of a scene - every point has a meaningful color, and we
don't want to see black.

I think this is the minimum change to fix the following issue.
https://github.com/facebookresearch/visdom/issues/623

## How Has This Been Tested?
Running on Linux, I observe the difference in safari.
https://snipboard.io/fkPFgi.jpg shows two scatterplots in the demo, one of which has no border. The same works for 3d plots.

fbshipit-source-id: 61dcfb591fc8644e0fed5bccaf48d547f74c7c41

Swaps video encoding from OpenCV to PyAV (#595)

Summary:
This PR swaps OpenCV's video encoding out for PyAV's video encoding.

## Description
The `video` method's had its OpenCV calls replaced with PyAV calls. I've also swapped from OGG(Theora) to MP4(h264), as it has [wider browser support](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HTML5_video#Browser_support).

## Motivation and Context
OpenCV is [a pain to set up with Theora on Linux](https://github.com/facebookresearch/visdom/issues/335) and it's a pretty hefty library too. This PR swaps it out for PyAV, which [has detailed setup instructions](http://docs.mikeboers.com/pyav/develop/index.html) and is focused exclusively on audio/video IO.

## How Has This Been Tested?
Ran the demo, all still works on OSX and on Linux.

I've tried to preserve the principal use cases of grayscale and BGR tensors, and floating and uint8 datatypes.

The one hiccup so far is that using `conda install av -c conda-forge` clobbered my numpy install with a conda-forge variant. I don't know if that's normal or just because the virtualenv I was working in was so messy. The use-your-own-ffmpeg instructions worked fine though.

## Screenshots (if appropriate):
N/A

- [x] Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)
- [ ] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality)
- [ ] Breaking change (fix or feature that would cause existing functionality to not work as expected)

fbshipit-source-id: 2ce3f91fcdb8c7cb92340cedf8122d2083103af3

Adding support for image click callbacks (#647)

Summary:
Adding support for callbacks on image pane. The coordinates in the image coordinate frame are passed as event properties.

## Description
A new `onClick` event is registered for `ImagePane`. I reuse the existing code in `handleMouseOver` to compute the mouse cursor location in the image coordinate frame. They can be accessed from python as `event['image_coord']['x'], event['image_coord']['y']`. I extended the python demo to register callback with one of the images; click coordinates are logged in a text box; see the screenshot below. As far as I understand, Lua API does not support callbacks at the moment.
I will update the documentation if the change itself looks good.

## Motivation and Context
It is convenient to produce visualisations based on specified anchor points in the image; I use it for my current project.

## How Has This Been Tested?
Running `demo.py`; the new functionality is working (just need to wait until everything is loaded).

## Screenshots (if appropriate):
![Screen Shot 2019-07-19 at 4 55 45 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1558328/61550409-4a28cb00-aa4a-11e9-8903-b4c843ef1519.png)

Removing lua torch support (#673)

Summary:
We're removing lua torch support, as it is heavily underused and keeping support for it has demotivated a lot of refactoring in the past. With it gone it should be easier to clean up the codebase.

## Description
This PR removes all of the python code that supports the lua code. I left the lua code present so that people loading lua from the most up-to-date repo will still get warnings properly.

## Motivation and Context
Lua support wasn't being used by many, and the upkeep for keeping the support was making it somewhat difficult to develop new features. As such, `v0.1.8.4` was marked as the last version with lua support, and this PR removes the related code. The `th` folder is left in tact with warnings for users to ensure that people running on the most recent version aren't just left wondering where torch support went.

## How Has This Been Tested?
Ran `demo.py`, everything from the python side worked as expected

Deprecating Python 2 support in visdom (#674)

Summary:
## Description
As a first step towards modernizing the visdom codebase, I'm freeing us from the shackles of python 2 compatibility. Version `v0.1.8.9` was tagged as the last version with python support, and will be left for any users that want to use python 2 with visdom. Future enhancements will be python 3 only.

## Motivation and Context
Python 2 support has become something of a burden (from testing to maintenance to merging new code - https://github.com/facebookresearch/visdom/issues/647 and https://github.com/facebookresearch/visdom/issues/595 have been blocked by internal python3 issues for a while now). Now

## How Has This Been Tested?
Run `demo.py` on python3, everything works well! Run `demo.py` on python2, get a notice to downgrade.

## Types of changes

- [ ] Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)

fbshipit-source-id: b69eb4b939daa299e0a4bdb8875d7a5b7a591c2f

Creating 0.1.8.9 release before deprecating py2 and th (#669)

Summary:
## Description
We will be moving to deprecating python 2 support as well as th support. In order to do this, I'm creating a release for the current state of visdom before  handling the deprecation.

## Motivation and Context
Maintaining both the th components of the code as well as dual py2 py3 support is overhead that the visdom project can't handle. We'd like to produce more substantial testing and refactor some older things, and removing these constraints from the design makes moving forward easier. Python 2 is officially being sunset, so it seems like an appropriate time.
Pull Request resolved: https://github.com/facebookresearch/visdom/pull/669

fbshipit-source-id: d210000de686c5f0d97d602b50472d5869bc6a49

Issue 659: Enable login env vars (#660)

Summary:
## Description
This PR addresses the feature discussed on https://github.com/facebookresearch/visdom/issues/659. The idea is to enable setting up login credentials not only using the command line prompt but also via environment variables.

## Motivation and Context
Providing credentials via CLI is not too convenient when writing automation scripts that should launch `visdom` server without manual interaction, or in any other cases when it would be more simple to set up credentials without prompt.

Relevant issue: https://github.com/facebookresearch/visdom/issues/659

## How Has This Been Tested?
It is a bit challenging task to write a proper unit test for CLI parameters so the introduced changes were tested running the `server.py` with various settings to make sure that the old behavior is not broken, and the new one works as expected. Below shown the commands and their output

1. Setup credentials via command prompt. (Default behavior).
```bash
visdom -enable_login

Checking for scripts.
Please input your username: username
Please input your password:
Please input your cookie secret key here: cookie
It's Alive!
INFO:root:Application Started
You can navigate to http://localhost:8097
```
2. Credentials via env variables requested but not provided.
```bash
VISDOM_USE_ENV_CREDENTIALS=1 visdom -enable_login

Checking for scripts.
*** Warning ***
You have set the VISDOM_USE_ENV_CREDENTIALS env variable but probably forgot to setup one (or both) { VISDOM_USERNAME, VISDOM_PASSWORD } variables.
You should setup these variables with proper username and password to enable logging. Try to setup the variables, or unset VISDOM_USE_ENV_CREDENTIALS to input credentials via command line prompt instead.
```

3. Credentials env variables provided,  but not for a cookie when it is requried.
```bash
export VISDOM_USERNAME=username
export VISDOM_PASSWORD=password
VISDOM_USE_ENV_CREDENTIALS=1 visdom -enable_login -force_new_cookie

Checking for scripts.
The cookie file is not found. Please setup VISDOM_COOKIE env variable to provide a cookie value, or unset VISDOM_USE_ENV_CREDENTIALS env variable to input credentials and cookie via command line prompt.
```

4.  Credentials env variables provided,  but not for a cookie when it was already created.
```bash
export VISDOM_USERNAME=username
export VISDOM_PASSWORD=password
VISDOM_USE_ENV_CREDENTIALS=1 visdom -enable_login

Checking for scripts.
It's Alive!
INFO:root:Application Started
You can navigate to http://localhost:8097
```

5. Env variables set everything.
```bash
export VISDOM_USERNAME=username
export VISDOM_PASSWORD=password
export VISDOM_COOKIE=cookie
VISDOM_USE_ENV_CREDENTIALS=1 visdom -enable_login -force_new_cookie

Checking for scripts.
It's Alive!
INFO:root:Application Started
You can navigate to http://localhost:8097
```
Every scenario seems to work properly.

Address issue #399 (#657)

Summary:
## Description

Allows image to resize itself to better fit the window. Resizing is done dynamically and matches its window resize activity. It is also now centered along the larger axis for better presentation.

When the user resizes the window, we want the zoom/drag settings to also reset themselves. This is because the image may go off-frame and disappear. We also handle edge cases where, for example, the container window is taller than it is wide, and the image itself is even taller than the window but has the same width.

## Motivation and Context

This change improves the Visdom user experience.

https://github.com/facebookresearch/visdom/issues/399

## How Has This Been Tested?

Manual test

Rebuild Visdom from modified source code. Run demo.py and add a small 32x32 px image to view changes.

Exposing polling functionality for logging.

Summary: Similarly to the usage for frontend polling, not everyone is able to open a websocket-based connection between their logging client and the visdom server. In order to better support this use case, this diff creates a polling version of the reverse socket, which is used with `setup_polling`. It also refactors the final request step out of `_send` to allow more ease in writing visdom wrappers that use alternate request formats.

Support for visualizing embeddings (#611) Summary: Showing zoom capabilities and summary view: ![embeddings-1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/425059/55255828-e9267e80-5231-11e9-9734-360252616457.gif) Showing the lasso tool and colored entities based on classification: ![visdom-lasso-optimized](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/425059/59636313-30315b00-9121-11e9-952e-ef3c94ac5afd.gif) ### To-Dos - [X] Visualize point cloud data in 2d form - [X] Provide a hover event which provides a way to relate to the original data - [x] Allow ability to select a subset of points and only perform visualization on those points - [x] Store a history of selected points to allow for a push/pop history view - [X] Auto-scale perplexity - [ ] Provide a mechanism to select embedding type and parameters to send an event to the Python-client algo (deferred) ## Description We introduce a new `vis.embeddings` method that allows visualizing embeddings via running the t-SNE algorithm. The visualization runs using WebGL, allowing it to handle thousands of points at once. The user can pan, scroll-zoom in and out, and hover over points to get additional information. Each entity can optionally specify an HTML representation defined server-sided. If specified, this will get pulled in and displayed when the user hovers over an entity. In our mnist-example, this is used to show an image of the handwritten number! We also allow re-running t-SNE on a sub-selection of points after the initial plot. For this we include the lasso tool. A minimum of 22 points must be selected for this to work. ## Motivation and Context This enhances visdom by adding the ability to visualize embeddings via running the t-SNE algorithm. It's goal is to make the ML debugging/interpretability experience easier. ## How Has This Been Tested? Example usage (from `/example/mnist-embeddings.py`): ```python from __future__ import absolute_import from __future__ import division from __future__ import print_function from __future__ import unicode_literals import visdom import numpy as np from PIL import Image # type: ignore import base64 as b64 # type: ignore from six import BytesIO features = np.loadtxt("example/data/mnist2500_X.txt") labels = np.loadtxt("example/data/mnist2500_labels.txt") vis = visdom.Visdom() image_datas = [] for feat in features: img_array = np.flipud(np.rot90(np.reshape(feat, (28, 28)))) im = Image.fromarray(img_array * 255) im = im.convert('RGB') buf = BytesIO() im.save(buf, format='PNG') b64encoded = b64.b64encode(buf.getvalue()).decode('utf-8') image_datas.append(b64encoded) def get_mnist_for_index(id): image_data = image_datas[id] display_data = 'data:image/png;base64,' + image_data return "" vis.embeddings(features, labels, data_getter=get_mnist_for_index, data_type='html') input('Waiting for callbacks, press enter to quit.') ``` ## Types of changes - [ ] Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue) - [x] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality) - [ ] Breaking change (fix or feature that would cause existing functionality to not work as expected) ## Checklist: - [x] My code follows the code style of this project. - [x] My change requires a change to the documentation. - [x] I have updated the documentation accordingly. - [x] For JavaScript changes, I have re-generated the minified JavaScript code. Pull Request resolved: https://github.com/facebookresearch/visdom/pull/611 Test Plan: See above Reviewed By: JackUrb Differential Revision: D15927868 Pulled By: pringshia fbshipit-source-id: 99c03fc2f23965845680883060f547360fcd93ba

Adds support for transferring env state to/from client (#631)

Summary:
## Description
Currently Visdom handles serialization with `save`, but this means that log files end up in a different place to the rest of the project. This PR adds a `set_window_data` function that, together with the existing `get_window_data`, can be used to serialize data on the client.

It also fixes `get_window_data`/`close` by changing `win=None` to `win='all'`, as `_send` assumes `None` means 'create a new window' and helpfully fills in `win=None` with a random string.

## How Has This Been Tested?
I've manually checked it works for setting the data of environments that don't currently exist on the server. It doesn't yet work for updating environments that already exist - what's the right way to trigger a reload on all the clients?

Fix display empty error when running visdom with base_url and enable_login … (#639)

Summary:
## Description
py/visdom/__init__.py. In line 471,
`resp = sess.post("%s:%s" % (self.server, self.port)`
was replaced with:
`resp = sess.post("%s:%s%s" % (self.server, self.port, self.base_url)` j

example/demo.py has been modified to take into account additional parameters :
`
 parser.add_argument('-base_url', metavar='base_url', type=str,
                    default='/',
                    help='Base Url.')
    parser.add_argument('-username', metavar='username', type=str,
                    default='',
                    help='username.')
    parser.add_argument('-password', metavar='password', type=str,
                    default='',
                    help='password.')
    parser.add_argument('-use_incoming_socket', metavar='use_incoming_socket', type=bool,
                    default=True,
                    help='use_incoming_socket.')
`
and:
`viz = Visdom(port=FLAGS.port, server=FLAGS.server, base_url=FLAGS.base_url, username=FLAGS.username, password=FLAGS.password,
use_incoming_socket=FLAGS.use_incoming_socket)
`

## Motivation and Context
When the enable_login and base_url are used at the same time when starting visdom, the graphics didn't display in the browser.

## How Has This Been Tested?
1. Start visdom with:
     visdom -enable_login -base_url /my_base_url
2. Open a browser at http://127.0.0.1:8097/my_base_url
3. In a shell command, run:
    python example/demo.py -port 8097 -server "127.0.0.1" -use_incoming_socket True -base_url "/my_base_url" -username "tom" -password "tom"
4. All the graphical objects are displayed in the browser.

Adding optional polling-based comms to frontend (#633)

Summary:
## Description
Creates piping to use the same API for both socket-based and request-based communication between the frontend client and the server.

## Motivation and Context
Up until now, the only way to communicate with a visdom backend has been through sockets. Unfortunately, in some network configurations, socket-based communications are not scalable or not feasible. To this end, this PR introduces a method to have both.

## How Has This Been Tested?
Ran the demo both with `-use_frontend_client_polling` and without it.

## Screenshots (if appropriate):
With:
![Screen Shot 2019-06-12 at 6 52 07 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1276867/59391980-03a5c980-8d44-11e9-8ac9-20d5d5e516f6.png)
Without:
![Screen Shot 2019-06-12 at 6 50 23 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1276867/59391982-056f8d00-8d44-11e9-8db0-9981228582dc.png)

Note that the batching element of the query-based version has led to a different ordering of windows. In observation this has to do with the number of times repack is called on different batch sizes.
